clinical_study.brief_title: Distribution of Highly Sensitive Troponin in the Critically Unwell & Associated Mortality
clinical_study.official_title: Distribution of Highly Sensitive Troponin in the Critically Unwell & Associated Mortality. The DIGNITY Study

lead_sponsor.agency: University Hospital Southampton NHS Foundation Trust

clinical_study.source: University Hospital Southampton NHS Foundation Trust

brief_summary.textblock: The current diagnostic criteria for a heart attack require evaluation of a patient's symptoms and ECG but importantly a blood test called troponin. With advancing technology this test has become more sensitive and is now called a high sensitivity troponin. This is a very effective way of rapidly excluding a heart attack if the test is negative. However there are a number of causes of a raised high sensitivity other than a heart attack, particularly critical illness states. In the absence of features of a heart attack an abnormal result therefore suggests that the heart is inflamed or unwell causing the release of high sensitivity troponin. The DIGNITY study will examine the consequences of high sensitivity troponin elevation in patients in intensive care and assess whether it has a role as a biomarker for predicting outcome.

primary_outcome.measure: Association between high sensitivity troponin and inpatient mortality on all patients admitted to each of the ICU environments at a large teaching hospital

secondary_outcome.measure: Distribution of high sensitivity troponin results for different admissions to intensive care
secondary_outcome.description: Distribution of high sensitivity troponin results in Medical admissions Trauma / emergency surgical admissions Planned surgical admissions Post cardiac surgical patients Neurosurgical patients

secondary_outcome.measure: Association between high sensitivity troponin results and duration of ventilation
Association between high sensitivity troponin results and length of intensive care admission
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Number of days not in intensive care within twenty eight days of original intensive care admission

secondary_outcome.measure: Association between high sensitivity troponin results and requirement for inotropic support

arm_group.description: All patients admitted to any of the three adult intensive care units (general, cardiac & neurosciences) at a large teaching hospital. These patients will have a high sensitivity troponin added onto biochemistry samples requested by the clinical team.

study_pop.textblock: All consecutive patients admitted any of the three adult intensive care units at a large teaching hospital that have at least one biochemistry sample performed as part of their routine care

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Adult patients (aged 18 years or older) admitted to any of the three intensive care facilities on site (general, cardiac and neurosciences)
- Biochemistry samples already taken as part of routine clinical care during the ICU stay
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients aged less than 18 years
- No biochemistry samples taken within the ICU stay
